@SmarterEveryDay The base film material has changed a lot from when I was doing some work at Eastman-Kodak back nearly 40 years ago.  Back then they used the bones of many large animals e.g., horses, cows, pigs, etc., to create a gelatin that was used as the structure for the film. It was lightweight, flexible, and the grain and transparency properties could be controlled to make a very useful product.

I've been an electronic engineer for 50 years, and have seldom seen such an amazingly good presentation of someting so complex.  This is a trip through Kodak's film production process - with the actual machines and the specialists who run them - from frequent revisiting of the overview to numerous fine details.  The host is superb at this - he keeps it moving, but is not afraid to stop and ask for more detail whenever something starts to get unclear.  He also summarizes what he's been told, essentially zooming out to help the viewer keep a perspective on what's going on.  He knows a lot about science, engineering, mechanics etc., and applies this to be able to ask clear, intelligent questions, and to draw illuminating comparisons with similar things in other fields of science and manufacturing. He keeps a positive spin throughout. The last thing I saw with this level of detail and attention-holding is a book called "From Dry Plates to Ektachrome Film," which I now want to re-read.

I found an old Kodak Report and used it to extrapolate some ballpark numbers. Final result = 5664.14 troy ounces of silver for every roll of film base spliced into the chain! That's $97,083.36 of silver per roll of film base at todays prices! No idea how many splices are made on a typical production day... 😮

No wonder Kodak used to offer a silver recovery program to film labs! Holy smokes!

In case anyone wants to check my figures:
-Kodak report specifies 12g of silver per 100 sq-cm of 35mm film (average of 6 most popular film products sold in 1998)
-Roll of film base is approx. 1-meter wide by 1761.744 meters long (per first video) yielding 17,617,440 sq-cm
-That gives approx. 176174.4 grams of silver per roll of film base (above figure /100 sq-cm)

Worked 30 years at the Roll Coating division of Eastman Kodak , where we made the support layer for all there different  Acetate film base in Bld. 53. They also made Polyester film base in Kodak Park in Bld. 317. Each base support is used for different film properties. Acetate was used for Kodacolor film and color Print film ,used for movie theaters. And color negative film used for shooting the original film shot on the movie sets. We even made the base used to laminate for Polaroid sunglasses. We sold to the Polaroid Corporation to make all there sun glasses. Also believe it or not we made all the different support layers Polaroid used to make there instant film. (That was all polyester support used for that.) Then they (Polaroid)sued Kodak after they had a falling out. While they were in court we continued to make the support layers for them because they couldn’t make enough support for instant film demand. Boy I could tell you some stories. Kodak was the greatest film company in the world and we truly were a family. Kodak had bowling lanes, six baseball fields and several indoor and outdoor basketball courts. A shooting range, with instructors. All at Kodak Park for the employees. We had three fully equipped fire departments and 4 ambulances and a 50 bed hospital with surgery rooms. Most all the divisions had full service cafeteria’s in all there buildings. I retired in 2011.
Very nice vid! Well done! When will part 2 & 3 be available? Thanks!

I used to process E6 (transparencies) as part of my photographic training back in the 80's. I used to process 5x4" and 10x8" transparencies and 35mm Kodak Extachrome. We also created slide presentations using a rostrum camera for various companies and I'd say I have processed thousands of rolls of film and sheet film. Never got tired of seeing the images appear at the end of the process. Squeegee-ing the film at the end of the process and holding the transparencies up to the light to check them was always a pivotal moment. When I was unloading sheet film from the camera back holder to the racks for processing I'd be in complete darkness of course and I had to check which type of film (negative, transparency, ISO etc.) from notch marks on the corner of the sheets, placed there during manufacturing. Was always a bit magical even though I knew well how the process worked.

This is wonderful.  Like some of the others, I worked at Kodak Park in the early '80s and had familiarity with the Estar Roll Coating division.  How fascinating to see an amalgamation of the old and the new.  The old pneumatic controls and classic wooden wide-roll caskets.  The newer CCD laser (quality) scanners and sophisticated digital controllers.  Great to see how the specialized knowledge needed to run the factory has persisted through several generations since I was there.  Can't wait to see the next editions ... particularly since film sensitization occurs in the dark (of course).

So Eastman Kodak is only a story about film at its birth and at its death. The story in the middle was of a chemical company that invented a number of amazing technologies (some of which are only being perfected now, like acetylated wood), and others which changed history. One of the major limitations of depth charges early in the battle of the Atlantic was that the UBoats were built to withstand TNT laden depth charges, significantly limiting their effect. The RN had known about this for some time, and developed RDX as a more energetic explosive for this exact purpose. The issue was that in a plant, a batch process is almost never economical, much less practical for making a high volume, consumable good for industrial warfare. The UK reached out to the US for help with manufacturing, and shared the recipe for synthesizing RDX, but it remained a batch process. Eastman developed the Bachmann process, which turned RDX production from a time and capital inefficient batch process into a highly efficient continuous process. The critical need for higher volumes of RDX in the context of the Battle of the Atlantic meant that Eastman's contribution, among others, was critical in keeping Britain supplied via sea and thus in the war.

Eastman Chemical is still a world class specialty chemical producer.

Destin, glad you were able to highlight this. I am a Rochester native, and even in the 90s it felt like every single one of my friends parents worked at “Kodak Park” as it used to be called. Much of the plant has been demolished, but it was a true spectacle to see as a kid. They’ve rented out quite a bit of the complex to other industries including using the old dark-rolling room for growing medical cannabis.

Kodak had its own fire department, bowling alley, movie theater, and even nuclear reactor.

Off topic for this video.  When I was a lad of ten my favorite thing to do on the plains of South Dakota was to go into the shelter belts and push over dead trees.  I was able to push over trees over a hundred feet tall and many tons by shoving rhythmically until the top of the tree began to sway ever so slightly, and then timing my pushing to increase the wave of force throughout until I would topple the tree.  It was quite the spectacle to see a little child uproot a giant leviathan of the plains with my feeble efforts.  It made me quite popular amongst the farmers in my area.  I know how to do it,(and I still can), and I know intuitively how it works, but I don't know how to communicate it to others. I have read of buildings collapsing, bridges breaking through this same mechanism, yet I don't have the knowledge of science and mathematics to completely explain the phenomenon. Please make a video(if you haven't already) to explain how the science accounts for small forces accumulating through waves to become so destructive. I cannot brag about my Herculean efforts as a boy when I cannot describe the physics behind them.

Yes, this awesome Justin, brings me back lots of memories because I did 12 years in the Army as a foto-journalist,  I still have my CANON F1, and my 2 NIKON F3 but been 20 years since I stopped using my cameras because of digital cameras.  As a  photographer, I had to learn all the processes with the film 35mm black and white (B&W) and color film. For newspaper prints, we need pictures with lots of grain.  That is where the ISO number on the film determines the sensitivity of the film other issues with the cameras as well are that I can't use them.  I had to develop my own film after shooting pictures.  In B&W the larger the ISO number the grainier the picture and the more light-sensitive the film is. To develop the film you need a total black-out room or box to transfer the film from the canister to the coil that goes in a large can with a cap that only allows the developing liquid in but not light. Three steps to develop the film, DEVELOPER, STOP BATH, and then the FIXER was the silver in the film is removed to preserve the image. Then you wash the film with clean water and hang it in a non-dust area, I used to use a tall locker to hang and dry my film. Then I cut the film by about 6 frames for storage and easy to make the pictures in the red light or orange lightroom. I also extracted silver from the FIXER acid using aluminum oxide powder.  In a large bucket the FIXER solution after a month of use, mix the aluminum oxide powder and let stan mix well a few times, After a few days using a coffee filter I filtered the silver powder after the aluminum oxide powder turned into silver powder. Well anyways love your show and a good job.

I can't take up your call to action (using a film camera).  I get the nostalgia part of it, but I exited film after experiencing inconsistent exposures between my Minolta X and the Kodak film I was using at the time.  Greens that weren't green, skies that weren't blue, and so forth.  And then there were the occlusions.  I had some of those in my Tri-X film that I used to shoot high school sports in the 80s.  You can't fix an occlusion if it happens to be right on somebody's face in your photo.  And it never really got better.  Finally in the late 90s/early 00s, I switched to a Sony digital, then to an Olympus, and after that to a Nikon digital SLR.  Now I shoot most everything on my iPhone but I still have the Nikon and some nice lenses.  I won't go back to film, not even for the nostalgia of it all.  Digital is where the power is.  But I will acknowledge that film is where you learn all about the fundamentals of photography, light, shutter speeds, f-stops, and film speeds.  Film is a great woodshedding for learning the craft of photography, for sure.

I used to work at Xidex Magnetics in Mountain View, CA, a floppy disk manufacturer. We used a very similar process for coating the media with magnetic slurry.  I was a visual inspector of the film. They would stop the whole process for me and I would take a sample of the film, about 18" x 24", and plop it on a light table, examine it with a magnifying glass (so low tech!), count the number and type of defects and report back to the guys if it passed or not. So much power, I had: if it didn't pass they would have to stop the run, clean the machinery and start over. There were several inspection points in the process all the way to the final product of an 8", 5.25" or 3.5" floppy disk where I did actual read/write testing using a 1980's HP computer.

Thank you, Thank you, Thank you Destin, I was a photo processor working in aerial reconnaissance for the U.S. Air Force for over 20 years. Can not even guess as to how many 100's of miles of Kodak film I have handled. Working with original and duplicating film off of the SR-71, U-2 & TR-1 as well off the old RF-4 reconnaissance aircraft and some others.

I toured the Kodak manufacturing plant in Colorado when I was in an advanced film processing class at Lowery AFB in the Denver area one year. That was a blast.

Only things I saw when I did visit Kodak Rochester was the small testing area when we were developing some new procedures with Kodak. Some were for 'new' 6800 photo printers. Heck Digital cameras weighed almost 10 pounds back then. People refer to them today as digital printers but back then they were brand new. These came in handy during Desert Shield/Desert Storm. Saved a lot of time and manpower.

Love the way you described the accumulator you were fascinated with. On our film processing machines we could run them 24/7 as long as we had film and chemistry due to accumulator at both the feed and take-up ends of the processor. Except that after a few miles of film the machine had to be cleaned and checked for defects. We only had about 30-45 seconds on either end to make a splice in the film or put on a new take-up roll before the accumulator would crash. When that happened all heck would break lose with buzzers and such. Worse was when you were processing original light sensitive film and this was all done in total darkness.

Cannot wait to see the other two installments.

Now check out the Kodak digital printing side located in Kettering Ohio. Been working in the commercial printing industry for 20 years as a digital print operator and been to the training school at the factory twice. Very neat stuff !

The "nuclear device" is the same thing used on paper-machines. It is a measures mass and thickness. It measures the mass and gives feedback to the extruder which I assume has actuators on the blade that deflect it ever so slightly to make thickness adjustments. On a paper machine the "extrusion" box is called a head-box the amount of mass being discharged is controlled by adjusting pressure, consistency and speed. The nuclear source is a gamma emitter. It used Cesium. A low level radiation but still highly regulated. Ours was ABB as well.

That accumulator reminds me of the vacuum columns in magnetic tape drives that served a similar purpose on old computer systems. The magnetic tape floated on a cushion of air over two rollers that spun in opposite directions. When the air pressure on one roller went from positive to negative, the tape was sucked onto the roller and immediately started moving at a well-defined speed in that direction. By switching the air flow between rollers, the tape could suddenly reverse direction, or stop, too. (This was useful when needing to reread a block of tape or to read after write, perhaps .) The vacuum columns, like the accumulator, allow for all this to happen awfully quickly while the electric motor driving the heavy tape reel reacted more slowly. For computer geeks who can remember back that far...

Also, film has to be handled very carefully to avoid static electricity, because sparking could cause unwanted exposure of the emulsion, even in the dark. This was particularly likely to happen when winding the film forward in freezing conditions (and maybe when rewinding, too). So we wound forward slowly and carefully when in the snow, etc. Perhaps a reason for an anti-static coating, as mentioned.

The process of making the film they put on those huge rolls is very similar to making the plastic film they use for vacuum forming for containers for cakes, and packaging of various products, and that process is relatively simple, but the end product appears to be the same. A machine like that might cost about a million USD, the machine in the video might cost 50 million. The difference is that the film in the video has to be perfectly uniform in thickness, perfectly transparent, perfectly flat and it has to be uniformly coated with various chemicals and the other one does not. So, to achieve almost zero tolerances, the whole process is not twice as but a few magnitudes more complicated. And that's insane.

U2 spyplanes are still used today. They offer wide area surveillance photos with extreme resolution that just couldn't be matched by digital cameras. They use KODAK AERECON High-Altitude Film, slow speed, panchromatic, black-and-white film. Similar film was developed and used in the spy satellites from the 1950s to the mid 1980s. Some satellites probably still use film. The film is returned to earth in tiny reentry capsules with a parachute that deploys. They didn't splash down, the parachute was caught in the sky with an airplane. They had a 90% success rate catching the capsules. Look up Gambit apy satellites. Kodak film made it possible.  It's said those satellites could read the headlines on a newspaper from space. Pretty amazing. With a digital camera of the same resolution that amount of data would be impractical to store with current technology.

Fascinating and well-done. I'd like to make a suggestion related to the accumulator. Visit a printing plant that has web presses and see how their accumulator works (called a "festoon" in the printing industry). It was the heyday years of the company with over 50,000 people working in Rochester alone. big bonuses were paid to each employee in the company every year in March, based on your longevity with the company. The filtration system is there because any plastics that have gotten a degree of burn or and sort of stray residue (grit of dirt) can get trapped in the die, which will split the main product. You also have to devise a way to extract said particle from the die gap; which can damage the die if not properly done. Die lips, no matter what extrusion process is machined and very easily gouged and ruined. Perhaps even the need of shutting down the extrusion process and disassembling the die/head of the machine to get the particle out. Depending upon how tight of tolerance the die is.

I really enjoyed this - it is very well done.  I have a near lifetime of interconnection with Kodak, and was really struck by how much more information they were willing to disclose publicly through your "episode".  Not too very long ago, I expect you would never have been able to get most of this disclosure.   I do have one observation though.  It may be a niggling point, but as it concerns the meaning of the word "film" it seems to me that perhaps it explains a little bit why sometimes those who have lived in the film world for a long time aren't always successful in communicating with those new to it.  That observation is:  I have never heard anyone before refer to the substrate (the base that the emulsion is added to - Estar base in this case) to be itself "film". "Film" is the emulsion - the neat stuff that they coat on to the substrate.  It is, in fact, a "film" coating on the substrate.

I was a co-op engineer at Kodak park between 1967 and 1971. I was assigned to the Roll Coating Division that manufactured the film base or support as this video calls it. At that time the estar base was a new product. Most film used the acetate base that did not have to be stretched. The dope was cast on the wheel at the final width. I will always remember working at Kodak. They did not want a union so they treated their employees very well. They had a camera club for employees that cost $15/ year. I learned much about photography and manufacturing that served me well in my career.

Fun fact about Kodak is they discovered the U.S was testing nuclear bombs way before it was public news. They discovered it by radioactive isotopes exposing dots on their film. There is a little secret that Kodak is not telling you about stretching films. In order for the film to stretch uniformly, it needs to resist stretching more as it thins. If it didn't, it would stretch nonuniformly. When softening something by heat & stretching, if the heat is applied AS the stretch is done (film is cooler than the air, so being heated by the air surrounding it), the thinner parts of the film will heat faster & soften & stretch more, accenting the nonuniformity, usually to the point of bursting. The dirty trick is to heat the film first (while NOT stretching), then surrounding it with cooler air while it is stretched. The thinner parts cool more, so resist stretching, leading to a uniform film thickness.
This is a trick learned by glassblowers. They NEVER blow the glass while IN the fire (unless they want to pop a hole). Instead, they heat in the fire, then remove & THEN blow to shape as it cools.

If you like the kodak film production process, you would love a papermill.  Same sort of process in the finished products area as that film drafting and tentering.  We use the same ABB scanner with a nuclear source weight gauge.    Similar turn up process.  You‘d love it.   Stepping back a second…. Wood chips come in and the bark is burned to make 1600# steam that runs turbines to make electricity.  Enough to export tothe grid.  That condensate is used at 160# to digest the chips and separate the fibers from the pitch.  That pitch is called black liquor and is burned in the boiler to make even more steam.  Finally the steam from the pulping process is down to 80# and used in huge dryer drums to dry the sheet of paper.  Many mills run at 4000fpm, tissue typically at 6000fpm.   You really should do a video on this.  I may be able to contact some mills for you to see if any of them would permit you filming.

Oh. My. God. ROLL COATING. This was my job at Kodak during the summer when I was in college. We went in on the B shift to clean the machines that were down with clear solvent. We had to climb into the machines on the second story (look out below!) and reach in to clean the rollers. It was 120 degrees in there.

Every machine has a blue police light on it for emergencies. One of the most common reasons the light went off was if an employee got a minor cut or even tiny scratch. Human blood contains enough lead to ruin a whole roll.

Kodak Park was much much bigger then than what you saw. Most of the plant has actually been demolished. It has its own fire department, bowling alley, stores, everything.

Just an interesting tidbit of history: Much of the film manufactured in their Indiana plant in 1945 had come out contaminated and unusable. Kodak scientist Julian Webb made the connection between the times of various activities at Trinity and times their plant was operational, effectively identifying not just that the Manhattan Project existed, but also identifying the Manhattan Project's goal after testing revealed that the contamination of the film could only be caused by cerium-141, whose source could only feasibly be the result of nuclear fission processes, and with corresponding weather data, were conclusively the result of the strange activity in New Mexico being blasted into the jet stream and deposited by rain into the rivers and lakes around Indiana as well as directly on the cities and factories. Webb apparently realized the implications of such results in 1945, and did not publish his findings until 1949. Kodak would eventually gain a special dispensation to be made aware of testing times so as to cease manufacture at the times of greatest contamination risk.
So the film is literally on tenterhooks :)

Dustin, I love your channel, and these multi episode series are just fascinating.
However, I dread a return to film. I know, film has a kind of romantic vibe to it and I’m vulnerable to it too, having started taking pictures in the 1980s (I still keep my Nikon F3 camera bodies).
However, the amount of noxious chemicals involved in the whole process (from manufacturing to development and print) is just too much of a threat to the environment to be justifiable, given the alternative does exist.
When digital surpassed film in every aspect (resolution, colour fidelity, noise, exposure latitude, etc) I said “dear film, I’m sad to see you go, but you’ve had your sweet time, now rest in peace”.
I understand there are arguments to be made against digital photography, and I subscribe to most of them (the most powerful is that with film, the social media lunacy wouldn’t be around and people would actually stop and think about things instead of of just posting a selfie on FB, IG, Snapchat, etc), but at the end of the day, weighing all pros and cons, film is not up to par with digital.
A revival of film is like a revival of vinyl for music after the digital revolution: not going to happen, thank Goodness
Fun fact: Kodak we’re the first ones outside of the Manhattan Project to know about the Trinity bomb explosion in 1945 because the radiation fogged their film

42:12 If this is what I think it is, it's a weight per area measurement device, based on beta radiation. I was a tech in a factory making these (not ABB.) I handled hundreds of these beta sources in my 10 year career. They are safe, as long as they are handled correctly, or not handled at all. Keeping such a source with an open shutter against your body would give you a "beta burn," but it would take a while, as these are under a curie in strength. If the source of radiation is xenon-85 gas, they have no ability to leak -- they are either sealed capsules or empty. The gas would dissipate to a harmless concentration, in just a few minutes after the capule loses hermeticity.

In the old days of film projection we also used 35mm accumulators when running one film print through multiple movie projectors. They accounted for variable projector speeds and distance between projectors. They are simply controlled by a weight, but worked very well. Disney had endless loop motor driven film cabinets that were long accumulators, long enough to held an entire presentation. These cabinets were motor driven, cooled and filtered that when properly set up would help a film print last for many presentations (20k+).

Bi-axial stretching (the tensioning and tentering process) is not unique to films. As a co-op student in college, I worked at a place that made parisons aka preforms (test tube-shaped and -sized precursors to 2 L soda bottles). To form the full-sized bottles, the parisons were inserted into a heated mold, a rod was inserted into the mold through the neck of the bottle and it pushed against the bottom of the softened polymer to stretch it axially, while at the same time, the parison was filled with pressurized gas that stretched the polymer radially against the interior of the mold.

You can see the chain orientation change yourself if you stretch certain types of plastic bags. A plastic grocery bag is usually a good example. When you grab a small amount and stretch it while holding flat, there becomes a point in which, even though its much thinner, the tensile strength dramatically increases and it will not stretch any further without breaking. Keep stretching and new un stretched material stretches until the entire piece is a uniform thickness which is much stronger and has almost no elasticity.

As a recent arrival in Rochester, I was amazed by the size of the Kodak operation.  But there's even more:  Eastman made his fortune without killing anyone.  The company has been most benevolent to this city--jobs, endowments to major institutions--music schools, the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra, it's symphony hall, museums--oh, it's quite a long list of permanently endowed community benefits.  All from "snapshots", as they say.  There are spin-off hospitals, medical schools.  Yikes!  For a city of 200,000, Eastman (George) has set up a pretty fantastic array of benfits.  Not THAT'S an example for the super-rich in this country to follow.

Destin, I don't know if this has clicked with you yet but in 3D Printing there are similarities insofar as drying plastic goes. A Roll of Nylon, for instance, will absorb water from the air so fast that just being on the roll while you print is long enough to add whole percentages of moisture to the filament. You must dry Nylon and other filaments before printing and use dry boxes to feed the printer. Even regular PETG and ABS will get too "wet" and start blobbing and stringing and require drying at some point, depending on the weather where you live and how you store your filament :)

BTW, if you 3D print, learn about what is a semicrystalline and how cooling affects it. Faster cooling = amorphous, less dense, clear, lower softening temperature. Slower cooling = semicrystalline, cloudy, dense, high softening temperature.

Don’t forget the transportation of film! It’s very special, you don’t just load it on a truck and deliver. Film is light sensitive and guess what RADIATION is? Radiation (the stuff that travels through skin, metal, and plastics) can’t be on the route that film is being delivered on. So a special route has to be followed to avoid Radioactive semi truck loads, nuclear power plants, and other facilities that produce radiation.

When you grab that old film camera, the battery may be dead and you can't buy a replacement. The mercury-based batteries used in the older film cameras are no longer available for environmental reasons. Silver-oxide batteries have a different voltage which will throw off the exposure meter. There is a zinc-air battery with voltage closer to the mercury battery, but they only last a couple of weeks. There is a battery adapter that will shift the voltage to the right range for about $40. Really handy people can modify the metering circuit in the camera by inserting a schottyky diode that will allow use of silver-oxide batteries. If the batteries rattle around in the battery case on the camera, use an o-ring  to secure them.

Destin,  One very cool photo that I do not think a digital camera can do is a Circumpolar shot. In a very dark area aim the camera at the North Star and leave the shutter open for 5 to 6 hours. The photo you get back is very cool and it will show star tracks of stars you couldn't see with the naked eye, and the tracks are in the color of the star. Oh and you need to use very high speed, low light film (above 2000 ASA) I did one and the resulting photo, which I had enlarged to poster size then framed, has two airplanes and one meteor going across the photo.

My Father and uncle started a photo business using Kodak products back at the end of WW2 when my father got out of the armed forces. They had to build their first machines to process film and papers. Later when they updated and bought Kodak's first colour film processors my uncle actually found design issues that limited the amount of film the machine could process. He modified the processor, showed Kodak what he did to improve the design and Kodak incorporated these design changes to their film processors. My family of three generations has processed film and photos from the B&W era,  through the colour film developments of 35mm, 126 format, 110 film, disk and Kodak APS  right up to today with digital cameras and dry labs. Thank you for doing this Kodak tour series Matt. I am sure that many will enjoy experiencing the real magic of film through you and learn how moments are captured.

This took me back to my days as a maintenance technician at a wire and cable company. The extrusion screws weren't 40' long, but similar in design to the one in the video. The extruders melted/mixed and pushed plastic or rubber-based compounds to a die and formed the insulating coating around the wire. Fascinating processes. However, I spent more time in the drawing department where drawing machines would draw up to 24 12gauge wires in and draw them down to 30guage for stranding. The machine sounded like a freight train (500hp DC motor driving it) and the finished wire was spooled at up to 6000' per minute!

The film days were great when you had a reliable camera and could send 24-36 prints off to be developed at Kmart for around $5. Once stores started scanning the negatives, digitizing the images, and using dyesub as the final product, instead of using the traditional optical process, everything went downhill fast. This was around 1999 or so. I miss how easy it was to take film photos and get back film-based prints and negatives. But I don't miss scanning to get images into the computer, or having to shoot slides to get the best clarity. It was a major battle back in the day to get a quality image for enlargement or print, whereas today it's beyond easy.

My dad worked at Kodak, Kodak Canada to be exact, in Toronto. He took lots of trips to Rochester. He was the purchasing manager there for many years. One benefit Kodak had was to hire employee’s kids who were going to College/University, to help them pay for school. So I had two summer jobs there as I was enrolled in the Fine Arts department Film program at York University. I was a night cleaner for one year (and learned about the VERY strict rules we had to follow if by accident we broke a fluorescent bulb, as the contents of the bulb could ruin entire batches of film emulsion, regardless of what building you were in). The second year I got to be assistant to the company photographer in the Communication Department and got to work along side the folks in the Marketing Education Center. It was such a great place to work! All THE BEST darkroom equipment - it was great. I even borrowed an 8x10 camera (yes, 8 by 10 inches for ONE image) one weekend and took some snaps around Port Credit Ontario where I lived. The 8x10 enlarger wasn’t set up, so I could only make prints via a contact sheet. So I still got 8x10 pictures out of it!

Thanks Destin! Great video, so looking forward to the next two! Oh… and I still have my old Pentax K-1000, maybe it’s time to bust it out and dust it off, and run a roll through it. I also have lots of old Kodak technical books and sheets etc. I used to love looking through those when I was a little kid as my dad brought lots of that stuff home (he was a photographer too). I’ll stop now, I could go on and on!

I work as a junior engineer at a company specialized in the web handling/converting industry/process and I can tell you that it is such an interesting and niche domain ! I learn everyday by working with old timers of the plastic film/printing/paper industry. The special part is when you realize that this process is used to make a big proportion of the products we use everyday, from paper, to plastic bags, to cardboard boxes and even roof membrane. I works everyday with the winders/unwinders, nip rolls (pressure rolls), slow/fast accumulators, etc.  It is a really complicated process with so many variables to monitor and to control like web tension, web temperature, sidelay shift, etc. If you think this is impressive at 250fpm, one of our client has a lottery ticket machine that works at 2000fpm with automatic splicers....

Most of the infrastructure there at the Kodak plant was built when hundreds of millions of people all over the world used Kodak film for all of their photo needs. Now there are still lots of niche applications for analog film, but the demand is certainly a lot less. If the demand becomes too low then it may no longer be economical to continue to manufacture it at that scale. When that happens, the plant may close and we may lose all of the experience and expertise that went into the process. I hope we aren't watching the end of a dying art. At least there are other applications for this beginning part.

Destin!...Back in '88 I spent two weeks in Rochester, going to the Kodak Marketing Education Center. I was trained as a "Kodak X-O-Matic X-Ray Film Processor Technician" so I could work with a company that kept hospitals across the northern two thirds of Wisconsin in film, developer, fixer, and other supplies...also maintaining the processors.

Did you have a 'Gennie' during your stay? A person needs to have a Genesee Beer once in their life!...made from the waters of the 'Mighty Genesee River' that flows through town!


I also have a 1940 Kodak rangefinder 35mm camera that was stored in a locker at the Hanford Nuclear Reserve during the later part of WWII. THAT you can't have, as it's the camera my father used to shoot his truck driving and earthmoving construction work before and after Hanford. He also used it to teach me the magic of light and film in the early '70s.

You CAN buy my Mamiya 645 Pro TL Medium-Format camera with standard lens, AF Pentaprism, auto winder, and several film magazines...I need money for a land purchase and house build! LOL!

P.S.: It's a pretty 'dark sky' area, so good for astrophotography...I'll let you visit, if you don't film or ask too many questions about what's going on in the garage...there'll ALWAYS be something going on in the garage.

Interesting side point to the flammable solvents room. The forklifts that operate in such rooms are required to have a UL rating of EX, or Electric Explosion Proof. All components on this equipment that could produce a spark are sealed against the environment to reduce the risk of explosion. They also use a grounding strap that is always dragging against the ground to discharge any static electricity before it can build and spark. Further, the forks, which are made of steel for strength are typically clad in bronze or brass to further reduce the risk of sparks.
Any maintenance and repairs on the forklifts requires the technician to ensure all of these protections are still in place and effective when returning it to service.

42:00 cool application of a nuclear gauge, often one would see them in level and flow rate measurements. Although they are also used in thickness, moisture, and density measuring.

A fun one is also the use in gas ionization, where a isotope with a strong and often only a Beta or Alpha decay is used to ionize gas.
Often the use of Beta or Alpha emitting only is to avoid the problematic gamma effects on personal, although X-radiation does occur with those isotopes.

In this case I'd imagine they are using either a Beta emitter or a controlled energy Xray tube. Although I believe I heard that it was a solid radioactive material, so probably Beta. Since you can determine the thickness from how much Beta energy is absorbed, or how much of the incoming particles are blocked.
Could be wrong they could be using a Gamma emitting isotope aswell since both are useful in thickness measurements, although based on the lack of thickness in sheilding to the operators Beta makes sense.

A note if they are using a Beta emitter they have to be careful, Beta radiation can damage PET. Although if they are I assume it's well accounted for.

Something I don't think they explained well is that the extruder has rows of heating elements across the width of the drum, and so if the nuclear thickness gauge detects that the right side of the film is too thin, the left side is perfect and the center is too thick, it controls the temperature of the heating elements in the extruder to make the film even all the way across.

I would guess it would either heat it up so it flowed faster and more was deposited on the wheel, or maybe heating it up reduces viscosity and it leaves a thinner layer.

From the description, I would guess that there's maybe 50 heating elements across the width of the extruder/drum, giving them a lot of control.
It might be fewer, but it might also be a lot more to get basically higher resolution of thickness control.

Very cool video. I work at a steel mill in Arkansas and we make sheet steel that is coiled up similarly. Although we are talking completely different products there are similar concepts. We take in scrap steel and melt 100k tons in an electric arc furnace or EAF. From there the furnace is tapped and poured off into ladles where the heats are customized to customer specs by adding alloys. Next step is to send heats to our strand casters. Essentially the ladles of molten steel are placed onto a turret the turret can hold 2 ladles and rotate over top of a tundish. The tundish is the transition to the caster mold. The mold is where steel is formed. The tundish acts as an "accumulator". It holds enough molten steel to allow time for turret to rotate the second ladle in place. Once in the mold material gravity feeds out the bottom to form a slab. The edges of the mold are adjustable to change width of product. We vary width based on custom but we run 65mm slabs up to 65" wide up to 2000" in length. As the slabs come out the bottom of the mold the are sprayed with water to help form and thicken the outer shell as the inside is very much liquid. The slab also runs through driven rollers that squeeze on slab. Material thickness stays the same in this part of process. As material feeds down the slab is slowly pushed and transitions from a vertical direction to a horizontal using guide rollers. Once horizontal it passes through a shear and is cut to a predetermined length again based on what the customer order. At this point the slab enters a linear furnace that actually adds heat to the bar to give it a more uniform heat throughout the bar. Usually slabs come from Caster at roughly 1700f and we heat them back up to about 2000 but this varies widely depending on what we are running. We have about 70 or 80 different grades we run and all have different metallurgical properties and have to be ran differently. The next major step is the rolling mill. At the rolling mill we roll the strip out to its final thickness and again its based on customer specs, but we can run as low as .060 gauge. We have 6 roll mill stands that squeeze and pull the slab to maintain width we pull as we squeeze. The motors for these stands are roughly 10k HP. In between each mill stand are what we call loopers. The loopers acts as accumulators and gives us excess material between stand by adding tension to the strip. They apply tension by raising a roll up into the strip this roll uses a hydraulic cylinder we maintain many tons of force at a specific angle. Any variations in the slab will effect the amount of material between stands. If the looper weren't there the slap would rip under tension or there could be too much slack and the strip will sag to the floor.  As the angle of the looper increases which would mean too much material the control system will start to speed up the stand in front or slow the previous stand down. All stands are connect by the strip and therefore any changes made to one will cascade to the other stands. There is so much more to what it takes to roll the slab out, but id never get it all in here. Anyways as the strip travels through final mill stand it will be at its final thickness. We also have an Xray gauge used to measure strip thickness if it's off the control system will make automatic corrections. The strip heads down the run out table which is a series of rolls and we have above them laminar headers which use laminar flow to cool the strip. There's much automation to this because each grade has to be cooled at a certain rate to a final temp. After passing through the ROT the strip finally heads to the coiler which is a big mandrel which secondary rolls that guide the head to the mandrel and the strip is coiled up. Our coils weigh anywhere from 35tons to 70 tons each. Pretty awesome process. I love it and I love watching other processes and see the similarities. Thanks for the content one of my favorites!

I made film in 14 room, bldg 29 it was the largest fastest most versatile film making machine in the world, I also was trained in 38 where they make film now, the only place in Roch now, 14 was better but different,  and they dismantled it many yrs ago now,a tad more labor-intensive, seeing the caskets brought back memories. Looking forward to the next part, they used to have a model of 14 machine in Bldg 28 Lobby, the path of the film was about a mile and the rolls were 12,800 feet long by 5 ft wide and the film was made continuously, no stops and one roll was cut and spliced to another with out the machine stopping, we made all speeds of 35mm (extremely labor intensive)and color print (easy) at one time 14 room even made instant film for Polaroid and then for themselves too, we made high speed aerial film too once used 175 gal steam kettles to melt it all down, each layer having it's own kettle, sometimes 17 kettles being used at once for really high speed 35mm and only 11 or 12 for color print. Even took a class 40 hrs, on how to make film and develop it and make prints. 14 Room is the long building on the south western most spot in the aerial pics...smokey glass stair tower

I worked for 3M in Oklahoma in 1990-91 at a plant that turned the big rolls of bulk photographic film into individually packaged rolls of film in the various sizes and formats. I already have a good idea what's going to happen in the final installment, but I always wondered about these first two stages. 👍👍

I shouldn't be, I mean this process was first developed way before computers. But I'm surprised how "mechanical" the whole process seems to be. I don't know why computers should be necessary, or how they'd improve the process, it just seems strange. Obviously over the years, the equipment has been upgraded and modernised somewhat (you can see digital readouts, the computerised scan of the film, thhw automated feedback back to the heater on the die, etc), but the basics of the process don't look like they've changed since they started in the 1880s.

The control room is a really curious mixture of old pneumatic equipment, old computer keyboards yellowed from age, and modern LCD monitors. Being the IT guy in an environment like that must be "fun".

This I know from being a technician for MeasureX, a U.S. based process controls company, for a time in my electronics career.
42:10 The radio active device is a thickness scanner. The scanner head, moving back and forth along the width of the material has a small bar or sample of an alpha particle emitter (such as U-232, for example) about the size of a pencil erasure. A read sensor runs aligned with the particle emitter head on the other side of the material and counts the number of particles that make it through the material. The isotope sample emits a known number of particles, and the material being scanned blocks a known percentage of those particles depending on it's thickness. The sensor reading gets sent back to the computer controller that adjusts the machine to produce thicker or thinner material. This scanning method is far more accurate and faster than any type of mechanical caliper thickness sensor.

The thickness is typically measured with a nuclear ionization gauge using an Americium 241 source. The source is filtered through a metal film to stop the alpha particles and only allow gamma rays through. Some of these gamma rays will be absorbed by the film and not reach the ionization chamber on the other end. By measuring the current produced at the ionization chamber the thickness can be measured very precisely.

I've once toured a large offset printing shop (biggest newspaper in the country), where paper is going through 4 offset printing machines at 11 meters/sec, then cut, fold, sorting and packaging belts. While I was watching, the paper ripped in the printing machine. Everything got stopped automatically within seconds, but at 11m/sec, a few seconds are 30-40m of paper, 3m wide. The workers then spent an hour or two pulling huge piles of scrunched up paper out of the machines, re-threaded it all, and spun it up again. A pallet-sized waste container got completely filled with rejected cut and folded newspapers, before the line was back up to speed and switched back to production. Very impressive, and apparently doesn't happen that often, so in a way I got lucky to see what happens when things go wrong.

I studied Optics at the University of Rochester and it's hard to understate how much Kodak has defined the landscape of that city. It was interesting to see Destin point out the red brickwork at the Kodak plant. The same brickwork is on every U of R building thanks to George Eastman. This is a wonderful video, I can't wait for the rest of the series. I grew up before digital, so film cameras to me aren't magic, they're still the old thing that I'm glad to be living in the "future" of. I remember the quirks of it, and the limitations of it. And, honestly, I don't like the tone of film. I know people are starting to enjoy that tone, but to me it looks washed out and less interesting.

That said, I do see value in keeping it alive. I learned things about composition with black and white film cameras that I don't know how I would learn them with a digital camera, and it's carried over into my digital photography today. Dad was one of those "amateur" photographers that bordered on professional, even teaching classes at the local trade school for a while, and he was very big on teaching us how cameras worked at all levels.

The main reasons I am fully in on digital right now are -
1. The richness of the color I can get out of digital. I know, in theory, how to burn and dodge film to get that richness, but I have never touched the tools required to do that in color and I only once developed my own black and white film. I don't feel that's what this modern fascination with film is doing either, it feels more like a return to the photography I did as a child where processing was handled entirely by companies like the one you toured in the previous video. I'd love to see development art make a comeback too - honestly I feel there is as much art to be done in development as in composition of a photograph. I know more about how to do it digitally and I've been able to enhance some of my photos in ways that amaze me with just dodge and burn.
2. It's not always intentional. I know people harp on how important it is to "be intentional" with important things, but there is also value in not being intentional. A lot of the best photography for an amateur is taking a moment in your life that you're just living, and capturing something that strikes you. A flowerpot while walking downtown, a view of a historic building through the trees while walking a trail, or just a unique point of view looking out from where I happened to sit down. You can't practically carry a film camera (or a professional digital camera) everywhere on the off chance of one of those moments, but with digital, and specifically the quality of modern cell phones, I can capture a photo now that would have required my father's SLR film camera and the right one of a set of heavy lenses in the 80s. There is still value in being intentional, but digital allows for the incidental.
3. I can adjust immediately while I still have the light. Most photography I do depends HEAVILY on the lighting. Sunlight gleaming off something, shadows highlighting details on something, or just the vivid color of a flower at a certain time of day. With film, the best I could do was take a few shots and hope one turned out. A professional might take a whole role of film on one subject just to have a better chance. I can take a photo, see what I did wrong, adjust, and dial in exactly what I want in a way I could never do through a viewfinder.

While I see the value in film and want to see people keep trying it out each generation, I think it's also important not to lose what makes digital special. We've gotten so used to it, but it's good to not let it become just a background thing but learn what it truly enables for you. I hope that those trying out film don't treat it as just a neat experience but bring what they learn from it to a new view of photography in general, whatever sort you take up from there.

First of all, the fact that Destin is able to go into places like this and learn about it while filming and showing us at the same time is just incredible. There is no one else on this planet that I would rather have showing things like this to me than Destin. Seeing the manufacturing processes and steps that they put the PET through, and how they somehow figured out the processes to make it happen, just blows me away. I mean, the fact that so many years ago, before many of us had even been born, these guys were working through how they needed to make the film, then they had to figure out how to get machines that would do it for them. I mean, it's not like they could open up the Sears and Roebuck catalog and place an order. Things like this are some of the most incredible and awe-inspiring things to see, in my opinion. While the industrial revolution wasn't all glitter and rainbows, as it caused many issues for society and humanity, but it's hard to deny that the people who created these processes and machines were some of the smartest and hardest working people to ever live here in the United States... And that also goes for a lot of other companies and people during the peak of American manufacturing and innovation.  So amazing.

The KH-9 spysat, launched from 1972 to 1986, shot the entire Soviet Union four times a year in stereo using mostly black-and-white film. The film was about 6.6 inches wide and shot past an exposure slit at 200 inches per second. The absolutely bonkers thing about this camera was that the direction that the film went past the slot (and the slot itself) would rotate by 120 degrees in the couple of seconds that it took to shoot one frame. Go reread that sentence, your brain was probably unwilling to parse it correctly the first time.

The film for that satellite was made by Kodak, supplied on two rolls that were 8 feet in diameter. The film was 30 miles long. To make that work, they had to get the base down to around 1 mil thick (the emulsion was a little less than 1 mil thick as well). The thin film was delicate, and they could afford no breaks because there was nobody to re-thread the film through the camera if it broke. So many of the film capstans weren't rotating wheels, but were instead air bearings. The film rode on a thin layer of compressed air.

After exposure, the film was routed through takeup reels in four reentry vehicles, so that it was first wound onto the last reel in the sequence. When that was full (every 3-4 months), they'd chop the film, close the capsule around the reel, and drop the capsule. The next reel in the line would then start to take up the film.

The reentry capsules would eventually parachute down, and would be caught over the Pacific in midair by a plane with an enormous fork on the nose, which would snag the parachute. They missed the first one but caught the next 75.

It all seems completely farfetched but I've talked to a bunch of the engineers on the project. They actually did it.

I think that "nuclear" machine is simply a beta ray thickness measuring device. It's a non contact measuring common with continous sheet production. It's a radiation hazard but not nuclear fuel level hazard.

Not sure how this works but I've seen it in a paper plant where the head is cycling left and right, much like a printer but a lot slower.

Another peculiar think at the paper plant was the cutting machine. It's laid across diagonally but paper comes out straight. Then I figured it out, from the moment the blade hits the paper. It's still moving forward. When it reaches the end, the paper would have traveled forward a certain amount so by the time the cutter reaches on the other end. The diagonal placement compensates for the paper movement.

You need to ask them some questions. How do you start up the whole line, where so many processes are serially dependent? There HAS to be situations where the process is disrupted, such as machine breakdown. This is obviously a 24 hour operation!
Regarding using film, I still do (but not for pictures of grandma on the porch), but for special processes (such as reducing for making computer-calculated holograms). All the B/W film I can get for 35mm camera has "anti-halation backing". This is a dark tint put into the backing to reduce halo producing reflections. This is fine for enlarging (just crank up the illumination or the exposure time) or scanning, but sucks when you want to put the film into an eyeglass frame. I had to buy sheet film, & in darkroom cut & tape piece into 35mm camera for EACH exposure. That was 10 years ago, & now even harder to get.

As a control system designer I'm blown away by the time lag in that system to control thickness. That has got to be some kind of wizardry. I wish you would have asked the time delay from the heating to the measuring system. It is like being extremely drunk and driving a car fast - the time delay through the eye, brain, musculosketetal system is so slow that by the time the brain processes what needs to be done next, it is already too late to compensate for the latest situation. Leading to crashes. It's the same problem with trying to control an economy (only much worse). All the Harvard educated economists in the world will never be able to control an economy (no matter how much they believe they can). Leading to booms and busts happening a random intervals. See for example all of the past governments that have tried it. The feedback generally leads to a long term collapse of the system.

When you talk about the accumulater and constant velocity; that is call a yoyou on the platter system that was used with print movies. On the platter system there are 3 to 4 reels of pirnt spliced together. The platters were horizontal with 1 on top and 1 on the bottom of the tree (vertical mount).  The takeup platter had a ring called 'the brain' which has miro switches. The switched controlled the platter speed.  Once all the film was off the supply platter the film was pulled from the center and fed through the proector and yoyo back to what had been the supply, no rewind needed.

I have had a Pentax K1000 35mm SLR since the early 90's. It has a irritating "feature" where it is easy to press the film release button, causing double exposures which ruined perfect shots and created some awesome unintended special effects. I love that camera. After vacations or big events I would end up with a dozen or more film canisters waiting to be developed.

But it has stayed on the shelf since the arrival of my first digital SLR. Photography is the one hobby I always felt guilty about. Between the creation of the film stock, to development and printing, physical photography relies on the use of many harsh chemicals. I eagerly awaited the development of digital SLR's and picked one up as soon as they were affordable. I love being able to click candids without thought of expense or environmental impact, as well as taking the time to compose thoughtful shots. I love seeing now everything is made, and I appreciate Destin's enthusiasm for the medium of physical photography. But the 35mm cameras are going to stay on the shelf.

I hope you took a tour of the George Eastman's house and museum while you were there. Fire was always a real hazard at the plant because of all the flammable chemicals they used. Because of this the Kodak plant and RR came up with an inventive solution of a railroad engine back in the days of steam Railroad engines.

We moved to Henrietta NY, just south of Rochester in 1967. One of our Aunts and Uncles came up to spend vacation with us in either 68, 69, or 70 to visit us. While my parents were at work and my other brothers were doing something else, my Aunt and Uncle took me to show them where the Kodak plant was and we took a tour there. I was also into model RR and learned Kodak use to have the the very few ever built, thermos steam engines for their RR. These operated by having an insulated steam bottle with no fire. There were steam fittings all around the plant the engine could recharge the bottle with steam to run, till they had to recharge the bottle again.

Quite an interesting process. The end bit was interesting too. I keep forgetting then getting reminded of the gap between America and the Philippines. In this case, it's about cameras.

While film photography was definitely a thing here, because most of it had to come from America and because, like today, there's a gap in both pricing and salaries, film cameras were definitely rarer here than in America. And while digital cameras via smartphones have given way more people access to photography, I keep forgetting that there's still way more people here that don't have access to more modern smartphones. What I do get constantly reminded of tho is again, pricing and certain other things that make other things less accessible here.

For us, even 1 GB of storage is huge, but in America, people are getting into TBs and PBs of storage. 720p is pretty much still HD for us while y'all are going into 4K. And while 5G is getting here, it's still very exclusive; heck, while 4G is widespread, a bunch of places still cap at H+ and even in 4G you'd be lucky to get 1 MB/s here, mainly due to costs but also due to geography. Famous consoles from both American and Japanese companies were relatively widespread in the US during the late 20th century and still are today, whereas over here they were considered a "rich people" thing and to some extent still are (although it's slowly trickling down to the lower-middle class).

I grew up several towns away from Rochester and my Grandfather worked most of his life in the chemistry department of Kodak. They had a very pragmatic-besides-scientific approach to developing new photochemistry. They had several teams of job-trained chemical technicians do experiments around the clock to test new ways to solve problems to produce a higher quality film for less. Unlike science, they didn't so much care how or why something worked, they more cared IF it worked.
I take Xrays now in the hospital system in Rochester, and I'm always running into Kodak vets asking me about the technology we use today. I tell them, when I was in school 11 years ago, we learned with film because film is truly the best at teaching photography fundamentals that xray photography and normal photography share. How they make black and white xray film is truly remarkable because the film must be so high quality and it's VERY LARGE. A lot of hospitals have barrels and barrels of old film that have thousands of dollars of silver to be recycled. Anyways, today virtually everyone uses 2 technologies in Xray, CR and DR. CR is older, it's like a reusable film scanned with a machine, it's much cheaper to produce though it's slower to operate. DR at least in my department is more common. It works in a similar way to a photodetector in a phone camera, in that it's instantaneous. Where photofilm is much smaller than xray film, the DR sensors which are 14x17inches or 17x17inches ARE ENORMOUS compared to the tiny, puny sensors in your phones and cameras. These plates we carry around and occasionally drop on the floor cost anywhere between 40-100 thousand dollars. But they take GREAT xrays and because they are Digital we can adjust the contrast which is super useful. At the moment spatial resolution of film is STILL better than these new DR detectors, but to be honest in the past, most radiologist weren't looking at an xray with a magnifying glass all the time. Hey maybe you could do a show on some of the new xray technology? I'd really like to see how these DR detectors are made! Carestream, a child company of Kodak makes good ones that I use, Canon may still make them, Samsung used to make them but they broke too easily and when Kodak made them, they made some of the best on the planet, they must have been a fortune to buy 15-20 years ago.

That was great! Thank you for the video. I used to work in a PCB (printed circuit board) shop. For a while I was the photo tool guy. The engineers would design the board and it would have multiple layers and each layer had its own pattern. We would put large sheets of film into a photo plotter and then a laser would "draw" the design onto the film. This was in a dark room. The film was ejected from the plotter when it was finished and then it would go into a developer. The developer was built into the wall of the dark room. The in feed was in the dark but the developed film came out on the other side of the wall in the regular light. The whole thing was really interesting but I never liked mess with the chemicals in the developers. We only had one photo plotter but we had multiple developers. If the was a problem it was always with the developer so we had two just to make sure that we always had one working. In the dark room, everything was painted black. The door was a light baffle so entering you transitioned from a normal light room through the light baffle into the dark room with black walls and a very faint red light that didn't expose the film. That transition into the dark zig zagging was easy to walk into the wall or someone else coming out. Your eyes need a little time to adjust to the dim red light. You really needed to know where everything was in there or you needed to closely follow someone who did. Thanks for the video. I am enjoying my James Webb Space Telescope Tshirt.

Very interesting to me as a film photographer for more that 50 years. I was also a newspaper pressman for 40+ years. You should look into what's called a "flying  paster" which uses the same accumulator tech to take up slack on a web of newsprint, (roll of paper) flying through the press at 20000+ impressions an hour, (maybe 600 fps). When you change a roll at speed, the flying paster takes up the slack in the web while a new roll is spliced on and then it's brought up to speed after the splice. It operates in just the same way as this accumulator does using a pulley system..

During world war two, Kodak was getting complaints about the film coming out fogged when processed. Kodak investigated the issue and found that the film had been exposed to radiation. They had linked it to the government's "munitions testing," which was, in fact, the Manhatten project. Kodak complained about it, threatening to sue. Instead, the government agreed to alert Kodak when a test was going to go off to protect their film. This agreement lasted decades. The government gave nuclear details, including weather patterns, predicted fallout, and radiation levels, to the film industry before even letting the public know of the dangers.

It is quite an interesting story. I highly recommend looking it up.

Weather Stripping for automobiles uses the same accumulator concept. There is a core that comes off large spools, is fed through an accumulator, and then into the die where it is formed and rubber is placed around it.  It was always a fun job to weld or stitch the new spool of core before the accumulator ran out of excess material.  Failing to do so would cause the line to go down and waste a few thousand dollars in materials setting it back up again.
Charles was awesome! Could tell he really loves his job.

Here’s a weird fact for you, in the 1980s my father helped engineer the worlds fastest camera, the camera literally worked at the speed of light. Not because it use lasers, because it could laser imprint every single frame on a high speed film projector five times per frame at 300 feet A second. All these years later, it still blows my mind, that the laser was imprinting hundreds of thousands of times per second per sec mechanically.

I cannot believe a facility this cool still exists let alone operates! It's awesome seeing so much oldschool tech you just don't see anymore at such a huge scale and high degree of refinement at the same time. Thank you for this!

Destin the thing that always impresses me with your videos is how well you ask questions. If the way they’re explaining something may be too complex for some viewers to understand, you yourself don’t break it down, but you ask specific questions to get them to explain it further. You get things simplified while always making sure they don’t look like they can’t explain something well!

I remember well the “good old days” of film photography. Being in South America for three weeks, lugging along a bag of film cans. Taking photos and not seeing the results until I got home sent the film to a lab, got it back up to a month after taking the photo. If I was unhappy with the results all I had to do was go back and do the whole thing again?
The only way to get better at photography was to have a notebook and note the exposure settings for each image so you would know how to do better next time. Did I do that? No, of course not. Did I get better? No, of course not. The final straw was when a photo lab got lint on all 30 rolls of film in the developing process.

It was like preparing a dinner for a large group without ever tasting anything until sitting at the table with your guests.
With digital I see what I’ve shot immediately and make corrections on the spot. As a result I’ve learned more and gotten better.
The idea of going back to film is as appealing as using goose quill pens and home made ink for all correspondence. Maybe fascinating but NO.
